b: ^When I arrive at the library, Charlotte is in the same place as before.
^She's seated on the sofa, reading to herself.
^When I arrive at the library, I discover that I am not alone.
^Charlotte is here, too. She's seated on the sofa, reading to herself.

Sofa: ^I decide to take this opportunity to spend some time with Charlotte.

b: ^] "Uh... hi, Charlotte. Could I, um, sit there? I mean next to you. I mean, you don't have to move or anything."
^Jeez that was awkward. Why am I so bad at this?
^Charlotte looks up from her book and smiles.
^[Charlotte] "I would be pleased if you would,
^"Begging your pardon, Charlotte. Would you mind if I joined you on the sofa?"
^Charlotte looks up from her book and smiles.
^. I would be honored if you would join me."
^] "Hey, Charlotte. Would you mind if I sat here?"
^Charlotte looks up from her book and smiles.
^. In fact, I would be glad for your company."

Sofa: ^I take a seat on the couch beside her.
^[Charlotte] "It's nice to see you in the library,
^. I don't recall you coming in here much before."
^] "Yeah, I didn't venture out of my room very often before this week. Seeing as I'm leaving soon I figured I'd best try and get out more."
^[Charlotte] "Well, I'm glad to see you here. Perhaps you can make use of my recommendations."
^She nods toward the notes affixed to the shelves.
Browsing: ^I feel a bit awkward approaching her. We don't actually know each other that well.
^I idly browse the shelves for a book, like normal.
^[Charlotte] "I would be pleased to make you a recommendation, if you're having trouble making up your mind."
^] "Wha- Oh, uh... it's fine. There's already recommendations, anyway."
^[Charlotte] "True, but when I write those recommendations I am unsure as to who the audience is."
^[Charlotte] "Usually, yes. Why don't you join me?"

c: ^] "Okay. I just didn't want to disturb you."
^, but you needn't worry about that. If I wished not to be disturbed, I would not be out in public."
^Her wording strikes me as odd, but I guess this is pretty much what constitutes 'in public' for us residents.
^] "Uh... no, thanks. I just came here to read. Sorry."

BrowsingRepeat: ^I decide it's best not to approach Charlotte.
Reading: ^[Charlotte] "Sometimes I can get another resident to recommend a favorite, but such occurrences are rarer than I would like."
^"Perhaps you would be willing to make one yourself?"
^] "Oh, uh... I don't really read enough to feel like I could."
^"Well, if you come across a work you like before you leave and change your mind, just let me know."
^] "Sure. I have been trying to read more."
^[Charlotte] "That's nice to hear. As I said before, I would be pleased to offer you a recommendation."
^"Do you generally prefer fiction or nonfiction?"

c: ^[Charlotte] "And how about genre? Fantasy? Science Fiction? Horror?"
^] "I like fantasy worlds a lot, so that probably."
^[Charlotte] "Quite a lot goes into creating such wondrous places. It's a hard genre to dislike, and an even harder genre to disrespect."
^[Charlotte] "A challenging genre, to be sure. One which asks us questions we are often afraid to ask ourselves."
^[Charlotte] "The most human genre of all, in my humble opinion. A wonderful choice."
^] "So what if I do like romance novels?"
^[Charlotte] "Nothing to be ashamed of! Romance is outside my typical choice of material, but I'm sure I can think of something palatable..."
^[Charlotte] "An uncommon preference, but one I think I share."
^"What sorts of topics do you enjoy reading about? Or perhaps you simply read a variety to learn new things?"
^] "I know most people are bored by it, but I find history really interesting."
^] "I really like nature, so I guess I like books on plants and animals and stuff."
^[Charlotte] "My father loves the natural sciences as well."
^] "I like reading stories about things that really happened."
^[Charlotte] "A grounded choice. You know I think you're the first person I've encountered with such a preference."
^] "I don't really have a favorite topic, so variety I guess. I do like learning new things, but I never thought about it that way."

g-0: ^She stands up and walks over to a far shelf.
^She returns holding a thick, nondescript book.
^"Somewhere along the line this fellow lost his jacket, but, I assure you, you will be no less absorbed."
^I take the book from her and look it over. It has a very humble appearance, but I am excited to start on it nonetheless.

Confessions: ^] "So you must read a lot to have all these recommendations for people."
^[Charlotte] "Oh, yes. I've been reading since I was quite young. I had quite a sheltered childhood. Books were my only companions until I was older."
^"I have been a reader my whole life. Although... may I confide something in you,
^[Charlotte] "I only began reading in public when I realized it would let me... observe people without arousing suspicion."
^[Charlotte] "Indeed. Well, I more study them, really. I find people fascinating."
^[Charlotte] "I ought to explain myself. You see, I have ASPD."
^[Charlotte] "Yes. Though I do try so very hard to be 'pro-social', dear."
^"The crux of it is that I have absolutely no sense of empathy at all."
^] "Really? I mean, you seem nice enough. Certainly not like the psychos you hear about on the news."
^[Charlotte] "I am very happy to hear that. I have made it my goal to construct a behavioral facsimile of it, you see. If you can't tell, then it's working."
^] "Well you had me fooled. In fact, I thought you worked here for my first few months here."
^[Charlotte] "Ah... Max is always telling me I do too much around here. Maybe they have a point..."
^[Charlotte] "When I was little I didn't understand anything about people. And is it not human nature to hate what we do not understand?"
^"I fear I was quite a horrible, loathsome child. But that's a story for another time."
^"When I matured, I forced myself to care. I resolved to train myself to recognize the physical signs of emotion."
^"I swore to myself and my family that I would never again act without regard for others."
^"I was prepared to check myself into Blackwell, but my family insisted I come here first. I know it's only a matter of time before I end up there, but I had to honor their wishes."
^"But I digress. The point of it all is that I took to watching people in order to better understand them."
^"I strove to memorize every action: to commit to memory every micro-expression, gesticulation, and change in posture."
^"And that is why I read in public. It's a kind of practice."
^Charlotte's eyes dart around my face before she breathes a gentle sigh of relief.
^[Charlotte] "My apologies for the monologue. You withstood it with aplomb, I must say. You are an excellent listener, do you know that?"
^] "Thanks for sharing. But I mean it was no trouble. I just sat here, really."
^[Charlotte] "Nonsense. I know quite well the struggle of strapping in while an oblivious associate starts over-sharing."
Questions: ^[Charlotte] "Perhaps you have some questions for me after all that?"
Trissa: ^] "So I noticed things seem, uh... tense with you and your roommate."
^[Charlotte] "What? Trissa? No. Certainly not. She's a charming girl. Absolutely delightful to everyone."
^"All the time, really. She makes it look effortless. Haha. Which is, of course, spectacular."
^"Why would I have a problem with that?"
^] "Yeah... you know, for someone who is apparently good at reading people, you're not that hard to read yourself."
^[Charlotte] "My mother once told me the same thing, you know."
^"Heavens, it's embarrassing to admit the truth: I've been... less than courteous towards her... at times."
^Charlotte recoils as if her own words had stung her as she uttered them.
^"To make matters worse, she has never said an unkind word to me... she has never reciprocated the unjust spite I have levied against her."
^. She may have a different sort of grace, but hers is so fluid and natural. She is far better at any of this than I ever will be, no matter how hard I try."
^"She doesn't understand how valuable her gift is! To be so caring. To be so empathetic. She has never had to work for such qualities as I have!"

b: ^] "Have you spoken with her about this?"
^] "Wow. Uh... maybe try talking to her or something?"

Trissa: ^[Charlotte] "Psh. Oh, I'm certain she would understand. She would be downright sympathetic, I expect."
^"It would only exacerbate things, my friend. I couldn't bear the thought of her pitying me like that."
^. It is, unfortunately, better this way. At least by distancing myself from her I can spare us both that pain."
History: ^] "You mentioned your family before. Could you tell me about them?"
^"The Blackwells are an old and wealthy family, though our wealth isn't old by some standards. My great grandfather, Winston Blackwell, made his fortune overseas."
^"When he returned home, he married and had a few children. One such child, my great aunt Viola, suffered from what we now understand to be schizophrenia."
^"My great grandfather opened Blackwell Asylum to care for her and any others from the community who similarly suffered."
^"Regrettably, my great grandfather gave his life in the war a few years later. Blackwell Asylum atrophied without his guidance."
^"It became a cruel place for the discarded. I fear it was not longer a place of medicine and hospice, but something far darker."

^"When my great aunt Viola died, it was a wake-up call for my grandparents. They shut down Blackwell and vowed only to reopen it when they were prepared to run it properly and the necessary restitutions had been made."

^"Blackwell did indeed reopen a decade later as Blackwell Psychiatric Hospital. It is, thankfully, a very different sort of place, where care for its patients is paramount, to which I'm sure you can attest."
^"My family is very touchy about this legacy. When I confronted them about my own condition, they refused to allow me to go to Blackwell. They worried it would 'reopen old wounds'."
^"So they sent me here to Sunflower House. If you ask me, they are simply delaying the inevitable. But I have honored their wishes thus far."
OutOfTime: ^Charlotte glances as the wall clock above the door and exclaims.
^"I have a routine to maintain. It has been a pleasure,
^Charlotte rises and takes a step toward the door before turning back to me.
Invitation: ^"Would you be interested in joining me for tea tomorrow?"

c: ^[Charlotte] "I usually take tea at 3pm, if that isn't a bother."
^] "Sorry, while ordinarily I would never turn down an invitation for free food, I've got other obligations."
^[Charlotte] "That's a shame, but I understand. Thank you for your company today,

g-0: ^Charlotte smiles, curtsies, and strides out of the room.
^I should probably head out as well.

Instruction: ^[Charlotte] "I just had a thought. Seeing as you're leaving soon, what say I give you some pointers on social protocol on the outside?"
^"I would be happy to tutor you in etiquette, if that would be something you would be interested in..."

c: ^[Charlotte] "How about here in the library tomorrow at 2pm?"
^"I usually take tea at 3, but I shall make an exception so that we have some uninterrupted time."
^] "Uh... sorry, I don't really feel comfortable committing to that right now."
^[Charlotte] "That's a shame, but I understand. Thank you for your company today,

g-0: ^Charlotte smiles, curtsies, and strides out of the room.
^Man, Charlotte is seriously living in a different century from anyone I've ever met.
^I should probably head out as well.

Fail: ^Charlotte glances as the wall clock above the door and exclaims.
^She curtsies and strides out of the room.
^Man, Charlotte is seriously living in a different century from anyone I've ever met.

^Oh, well. I guess I'd better head out, too.
